text:
For far too long,
people have sorted themselves
into two camps--

those who are creative
and those who aren't.

Like any trait,
self-selected, non-creatives

have believed they were simply
born without the creative gene.

But according to bestselling
author Joseph Grenny,

creativity is
actually learnable.

Grenny arrived at
this revelation

when he found himself
in way over his head
on a project in Kenya.

He'd been tasked with
generating self-help strategies

to propel Kenya's
poorest citizens
up the economic ladder.

The problem was Grenny had
zero experience doing this.

So like all of us, he hoped and
prayed that ideas would come,
and they did.
The project was a success.

But in hindsight,
Grenny realized

he'd actually been doing
much more than merely

invoking help from the
heavens for solutions.

Grenny's great takeaway was
that, while no one can isolate

all of the variables
that summon imagination,

he had reliably created the
conditions that invited it.

Perhaps more
importantly, Grenny saw

that anyone can make themselves
more predictably creative

by following the
same principles.

One of Grenny's ideas
for inviting innovation
is to frame the problem at hand.

Once the problem is
clearly articulated,

step back and allow the
problem to turn in your mind.

Like a grain of
sand in an oyster,

the cognitive irritation
stimulates creativity,

and the unconscious
gets to work.

Another creativity conjuring
tip is to obey your curiosity.

This means following paths
that have no obvious purpose
other than to satisfy a whim.

Maybe it's reading an
article that catches your eye

or attending a conference
session that intrigues you.

It's tempting to let
these opportunities pass.

But if you do, it could be
at your own creative peril.

If creativity is just connecting
things, as some have said,

you'll be more creative if you
have more things to connect.

But Grenny says
you should also do
things that don't interest you.

This can be difficult
advice to follow.

No one wants to watch that
boring looking video someone
sent.

But lots of tasks that
begin as a chore often
end with an insight.

Sometimes we call
things boring simply

because they lie outside
the box we're currently in.

As for boxes, Grenny
recommends that you

keep a shoebox or
something similar to store

your experiences and that
you revisit it often.

If you are obeying
your curiosity

and doing things that
don't interest you,

that shoe box will be
chock full of new ideas
before you know it.

Grenny also advises
that we invite
uncomfortable conversations.

You'd be surprised
by what you can

learn from discussions
with people

you might not
normally engage with.

Debating politics with someone
from an opposing party,

questioning a con artist, or
exploring the idea of home

with a child refugee
forces us to grapple

with another's perspective and
expands our powers of empathy.

And Grenny's final idea
for summoning creativity,

when you feel creativity hit,
stop whatever else you're doing
and focus on it.

We know when inspiration
is brewing inside of us.

The trick is to respect
these moments by jotting down
our thoughts as they come.

Ignore these moments or try
to kick them down the road,

and they'll be nearly
impossible to re-summit.

Sure, creativity may
always be part mystery.

But by following
Grenny's advice,
we can all invite it's arrival.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
